stimulusHtml:
Respond to parts A, B, and C.

 

  1. Describe one specific contribution made by an African American to scientific or technological advances after 1900.  

  2. Describe one conclusion that can be drawn from the data in the graphs. 

  3. Explain how changes in the 1950s and 1960s provide a helpful context for understanding the data in the graphs.

features.html:
Source 1

  • All values are approximate.

  • The following five lines are shown:

    • White

    • Hispanic

    • Asian/Pacific Islander

    • African American

    • Indigenous American

  • The White line:

    • Begins at 1980, 115

    • Remains level to 1985, 115

    • Falls gradually to 1990, 110

    • Falls gradually to 1995, 105

    • Remains level to 2000, 105

    • Remains level to 2005, 105

    • Remains level to 2010, 105

    • Falls gradually to 2015, 103

    • Falls gradually to 2020, 100

  • The Hispanic Line:

    • Begins at 1980, 45

    • Rises gradually to 1985, 47

    • Rises gradually to 1990, 49

    • Rises gradually to 1995, 50

    • Remains level to 2000, 50

    • Falls gradually to 2005, 45

    • Rises gradually to 2010, 49

    • Rises gradually to 2015, 50

    • Rises gradually to 2020, 55

  • The Asian/Pacific Islander line:

    • Begins at 1980, 160

    • Rises gradually to 1985, 175

    • Rises gradually to 1990, 200

    • Rises sharply to 1995, 260

    • Rises gradually to 2000, 280

    • Falls gradually to 2005, 250

    • Falls gradually to 2010, 235

    • Falls gradually to 2015, 225

    • Falls gradually to 2020, 210

  • The African American Line:

    • Begins at 1980, 47

    • Remains level to 1985, 47

    • Rises gradually to 1990, 49

    • Rises gradually to 1995, 52

    • Rises gradually to 2000, 55

    • Rises gradually to 2005, 60

    • Rises gradually to 2010, 65

    • Rises gradually to 2015, 75

    • Rises gradually to 2020, 85

  • The Indigenous American Line:

    • Begins at 1980, 70

    • Falls gradually to 1985, 60

    • Falls gradually to 1990, 55

    • Rises sharply to 1995, 100

    • Remains level to 2000, 100

    • Rises gradually to 2005, 125

    • Falls gradually to 2010, 100

    • Falls gradually to 2015, 75

    • Falls gradually to 2020, 55

 

The Brookings Institution

 

 

Source 2

  • The data for the seven sections are as follows:

    • Physical Sciences: 4%

    • Engineering: 5%

    • Humanities: 9%

    • Other: 9%

    • Life Sciences: 14%

    • Social Sciences: 18%

    • Education: 41%

The Journal of Blacks in Higher Education
